{{Expand Croatian|Glavni stožer Oružanih snaga Republike Hrvatske|date=May 2013|topic=gov}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name='''General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Croatia'''
''Glavni stožer Oružanih snaga Republike Hrvatske'' |image=Seal of Armed General Staff of the Armed Forces of Croatia.png |image_size=150px |caption=Croatian General Staff emblem |dates=1991–present |country={{flag|Croatia}} |allegiance=[[File:Seal of Armed Forces of Croatia.png|23px]] [[Republic of Croatia Armed Forces|Armed Forces]] |branch=[[Active duty]] |type=[[Staff (military)|Staff]] |role= |size= |command_structure=[[Ministry of Defence (Croatia)|Ministry of Defence]] |garrison=[[Zagreb]] |commander1=[[General]] [[Mirko Šundov]] |commander1_label=Current Chief of General Staff |commander2=[[Stožerni general|General of the Army]] [[Anton Tus]] |commander2_label=First Chief of General Staff }} '''General Staff of the [[Republic of Croatia Armed Forces|Armed Forces]] of the [[Croatia|Republic of Croatia]]''' ({{Lang-hr|Glavni stožer Oružanih snaga Republike Hrvatske}}) is a joint body organized within the [[Ministry of Defence (Croatia)|Ministry of Defence]]. It is responsible for development, organization, and equipping, training and functioning of the first strategic echelon (stand-by forces) and the other strategic echelon (reserve). General Staff is responsible for the command, preparation and use of the Armed Forces. General Staff commands the entire Armed Forces in accordance with the dictates of the Commander-in-Chief ([[President of Croatia]]) and the Minister of Defense and perform other professional activities for the Commander-in-Chief and the Minister of Defense. The main headquarters of the General Staff is located in [[Zagreb]]. ==Chief of General Staff== {{main|Chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Croatia}} At the head of the General Staff is the '''[[Chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Croatia|Chief of Staff]]''' who is superior to commands, units and institutions of the Armed Forces. Chief of Staff is the chief military adviser to the Commander-in-Chief and the Minister of Defense. Chief of Staff can be appointed for a period of five years and may be appointed for no more than two times. The current Chief of the General Staff is General [[Mirko Šundov]]. ==See also== * [[Republic of Croatia Armed Forces]] {{Croatia topics|state=collapsed}} {{Military of Croatia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:General Staff Of The Armed Forces Of The Republic Of Croatia}} [[Category:Military of Croatia]] {{Europe-mil-stub}} {{Croatia-stub}}

revision.text:
{{about|a historical administrative term in Poland|its usage in Ukraine|Hromada|its usage in Belarus|Hramada|other uses}} '''Gromada''' {{IPAc-pl|g|r|o|'|m|a|d|a|}} is a [[Polish language|Polish]] word meaning "gathering", "group", or "assembly". In the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]], the term referred to a [[village]] organization which embraced all the inhabitants of a village and acted as a local authority, as well as overseeing [[tax]] payments. In this sense the gromada developed between the 16th and 18th centuries, and continued to function in [[Congress Poland]]. Their chiefs took the title of [[sołtys]] and were elected by the local population. The gromada continued to function in [[interwar Poland]], as a subdivision of a [[gmina]]. In [[Polish People's Republic|communist Poland]] between 1954 and 1972, gromadas constituted the lowest tier of local government, taking over the role previously played by gminas. A gromada would generally consist of several villages, but they were smaller units than the gminas had been. In 1973 gminas were reintroduced and gromadas abolished. At present the smallest unit of local government in rural Poland (subordinate to the gmina) is the [[sołectwo]]. A gromada is a former Polish unit of local government e.g. * [[Gromada Osiek]] * [[Gromada Tursko Wielkie]] ==See also== * [[Hromada]] * [[Hramada]]
{{Polish terms for country subdivisions}} [[Category:Types of country subdivisions]] [[Category:Subdivisions of Poland]] {{Poland-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox University |name = Københavns Erhvervsakademi |image = |image_caption = |native_name = |image_name = |latin_name = |motto = |established = 2009 |type = [[University of Applied Sciences]] |endowment = |staff = 350 |students = 4717 full-time (2015)
3,907 part-time (2015) |faculty = |president = |principal = |rector = |chancellor = |vice_chancellor = |dean = |head_label = |head = |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |city = [[Copenhagen]] |state = |country = [[Denmark]] |campus = |free_label = |free = |colors = |colours = |mascot = |affiliations = |website = [http://www.kea.dk/en/ www.kea.dk] }} '''KEA – Copenhagen School of Design and Technology''' ([[Danish language|Danish]]: Københavns Erhvervsakademi, usually referred to as '''KEA'''), is a school of [[higher education]] in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. The academy is an independent self-owning institution subordinated to the [[Ministry of Science, Innovation and Higher Education (Denmark)|Ministry of Science, Innovation and Higher Education]]. Degree programmes offerered are mainly applied degrees, especially in design, technology and IT. The academy grant undergraduate and academic degrees but not master's or doctoral degrees. In addition to full-time studies the academy offers supplemental education, part-time programmes at [[bachelor]]'s level and short-term courses for people who need to strengthen their qualifications. With 4,717 full-time students and 3,907 part-time students and about 350 employees as of 2015, the academy is one of the largest business academies in Denmark. ==Campus== KEA currently consists of 8 different locations, most of which are concentrated in the districts of [[Nørrebro]] and [[Bispebjerg|North West]]. The main campus, KEA Guldbergsgade, occupies a dense site in the area between [[Guldbergsgade]], [[Mimersgade]], Peter Fabers Gade and [[Nørrebrogade]]. It opened in 2013, designed by Bertelsen & Scheving Arkitekter and is partly located in a converted 4-story industrial building from the 1950s, a former printing business.{{cite web|url=http://bsarkitekter.dk/campus-empire-n%C3%B8rrebro/|title=Fra industry til undervisning|language=Danish|publisher=Bertelsen & Scheving Arkitekter|accessdate=25 September 2015}} The other buildings are located on Prinsesse Charlottes Gade (No. 38)in Nørrebro, Bispevej (No, 5) and Lygten (No. 16 and 37( in North West, Lersø Parkallé )No. 2), Landskronagade (No. 64) and Rosenvængets Allé (No. 20B) and Frederikkevej (No. 8) in [[Hellerup]]. The Landskronagade campus tenancy was terminated in 2016, and operations were moved out in the summer of 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kea.dk/fileadmin/user_upload/Om_KEA/Organisation/KEA_AARSRAPPORT_16_A4_purple_Final_2.pdf|title=KEA Københavns Erhvervsakademi Årsrapport 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=www.kea.dk|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==Programmes== === Academy Profession Degree Programme === * Computer science * Design, technology and business * IT technology * Multimedia design and communication * Production technology ===Top-up Bachelor's degrees === * E-Concept Development * Design & Business * Software Development * Web Development * Product Development & Interactive Development === Bachelor's degrees === * Architectural Technology and Construction Management * Business, Economics and IT * Jewellery, Technology and Business ==References== {{reflist|1}} ==External links== * [http://www.kea.dk/en/ Official website] * [https://www.ug.dk/institution/kea-koebenhavns-erhvervsakademi-landskronagade-kea-landskron Profile] on the Education Guide website of the Danish [[Ministry of Science, Innovation and Higher Education (Denmark)|Ministry of Science, Innovation and Higher Education]] * [https://www.retsinformation.dk/ Translations of Danish educational terms through proclamations of the [[Ministry of Science, Innovation and Higher Education (Denmark)|Ministry of Science, Innovation and Higher Education]]] {{DEFAULTSORT:KEA - Copenhagen School of Design and Technology}} [[Category:Higher education in Copenhagen]] {{Denmark-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Kulm law''', '''Culm law''' or '''Chełmno Law''' ({{lang-de|Kulmer Recht}}; {{lang-lat|Jus Culmense vetus}}; {{lang-pl|Prawo chełmińskie}}) was a legal [[constitution]] for a [[municipal]] [[form of government]] used in several Central European cities during the [[Middle Ages]].
It was initiated on 28 December 1233 in the [[Monastic State of the Teutonic Knights]] by [[Hochmeister]] [[Hermann von Salza]] and [[Hermann Balk]] when the towns of [[Toruń|Thorn]] (Toruń) and [[Chełmno]] (Kulm) received [[German town law]], in particular as a modification of [[Magdeburg rights]]. Named after the town it was signed in, the original document was lost in 1244 when the town hall burned due to an attack by [[Swantopolk II, Duke of Pomerania]]. The renewed charter of 1 October 1251 was based on a copy in Thorn, but the rights were reduced.
This type of law was mostly granted by the [[Teutonic Order]] to cities within their monastic state, but also adopted by cities elsewhere, mainly in the neighboring independent [[Duchy of Masovia]]. In addition, the Kulm law was expanded, independently from the Knights, to a larger set of laws called ''[[Alter Kulm]]''.
Cities located under Kulm law include: {| class="wikitable" |- ! In the Monastic state of Prussia ! In independent [[Duchy of Masovia]] |- valign="top" | *[[Chełmno|Kulm]] (Chełmno) - 1233 *[[Toruń|Thorn]] (Toruń) - 1233 *[[Marienwerder]] (Kwidzyn) - 1233 *[[Klaipėda|Memel]] (Klaipėda) - 1258 *[[Königsberg]] (Kaliningrad) - 1286 *[[Graudenz]] (Grudziądz) - 1291 *[[Deutsch Eylau]] (Iława) - 1305 *[[Soldau]] (Działdowo) - 1344 *[[Bytów|Bütow]] (Bytów) - 1346 *[[Allenstein]] (Olsztyn) - 1348 *[[Baldenburg]] (Biały Bór) - 1395 | *[[Płock]] - 1237 *[[Warsaw]] - 1334 *[[Różan]] - 1378 *[[Czersk]] - 1386 *[[Ciechanów]] - 1400 *[[Łomża]] - 1418 *[[Liw, Poland|Liw]] - 1421 *[[Kolno]] - 1425 *[[Tykocin]] - 1425 *[[Przasnysz]] - 1427 *[[Mława]] - 1429 *[[Radzymin]] - 1475 *[[Niedzbórz]] - 1505 |}
== See also == *[[German town law]] *[[Lübeck law]] *[[Magdeburg rights]] *[[History of Prussia]] *[[Håndfæstning]], [[Handfeste]]
== Literature == * Jus Culmense ex ultima revisione, oder das vollständige culmische Recht, mit Anmerkungen, Danzig 1767 [https://books.google.com/books?id=5ykVAAAAQAAJ] [https://books.google.com/books/pdf/Jus_Culmense_ex_ultima_revisione__oder_d.pdf?id=5ykVAAAAQAAJ&output=pdf&sig=ACfU3U3IpSQju7RCdNla9P0CtRJLjFE6hg&source=gbs_summary_r&cad=0] * Danuta Janicka: Nauka o winie i karze w dziejach klasycznej szkoły prawa karnego w Niemczech w 1 połowie XIX wieku, Toruń: Wydaw. Uniwersytetu Mikołaja Kopernika, 1998, {{ISBN|83-231-0985-0}} * Danuta Maria Janicka: Prawo karne w trzech rewizjach prawa chełmińskiego z XVI wieku, Toruń: TNT, 1992, {{ISBN|83-85196-50-1}} * Peter Johanek: Artikel 'Alter Kulm' in Kurt Ruh u.a. (Hg.): Die deutsche Literatur des Mittelalters. Verfasserlexikon Bd. 2, Berlin u.a. 2. Auflage 1978, Sp. 267-269 * Alexander Rogatschewski: Zur Geschichte des 'Alten Kulms' und anderer preußischer Rechtsbücher nach St. Petersburger Quellen, in: R.G. Päsler/D. Schmidtke (Hg.): Deutschsprachige Literatur des Mittelalters im Östlichen Europa. Forschungsstand und Forschungsperspektiven, Heildelberg 2006, S. 199-244 * Ralf G. Päsler: Deutschsprachige Sachliteratur im Preußenland bis 1500. Untersuchungen zu ihrer Überlieferung, Köln u.a. 2003, S. 197, 222-224 und 243-252
[[Category:Legal history of Germany]] [[Category:Urban planning in Germany]] [[Category:Kulm law| ]]

{{Infobox newspaper| name = Le Quotidien | type = Daily newspaper | format = Broadsheet| foundation = 24 February 2003| ceased publication = | owners = Avenir Communications SA| political = opposition| circulation = | headquarters = Sodida , Rue 14 prolongée
B.P : 25835 [[Dakar]] , [[Senegal]] | editor = Madiambal Diagne| website = [http://www.lequotidien.sn lequotidien.sn] }} '''''Le Quotidien''''' is a major independent daily [[newspaper]] in [[Senegal]], based in the capital of [[Dakar]]. It also publishes a glossy weekly, entitled ''Week end''.[http://www.buyusa.gov/westafrica/en/senegal_ccg.pdf Senegal Country Commercial Guide 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507200048/http://www.buyusa.gov/westafrica/en/senegal_ccg.pdf |date= 7 May 2009 }}. [[U.S. Commercial Service]] (2008). {{PD-notice}} ==Launch== Launched by owner/editor Madiambal Diagne—a former reporter for Dakar's [[Wal Fadjri]] -- and his [[Avenir Communications SA]] company in February 2003, Le Quotidien is generally critical of the government, as well as political and religious figures.One example is the unsigned editorial [http://www.lequotidien.sn/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=656&Itemid=13 CIMETIERE HOMO], 8 August 2008, in which the paper criticises government, religious, and cultural leaders for their intolerance towards homosexuality, a major taboo in Senegalese society. ==Controversy== In July 2004 Diange was arrested pending charge by the government for publishing articles alleging fraud in the customs service and government interference in the judiciary. The arrest came from an alleged breach of Article 80 of the Penal Code, which mandates up to 5 years in jail for anyone convicted of "acts that might compromise public security or cause serious political problems."[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/publisher,CPJ,,SEN,47c566ee2d,0.html UNHCR: Attacks on the Press in Senegal, 2004] He was released following international pressure and a press strike.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3886269.stm Senegal's Day Without Press], BBC, 12 July 2004. ==Expansion== In 2006, Le Quotidien purchased its own press facilities, freeing it from use of government owned printing facilities. In 2007 the company's attempt to launch a sister radio station in Dakar was halted by the government, but [[Premiere FM]] opened after appeal at the end of that year. ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.mdlf.org/en/mdlf/July2007/918/ Senegal radio station to launch after police raid], [[Media Development Loan Fund]], July 2007. *[http://www.afdevinfo.com/htmlreports/org/org_39664.html African Development Information Services: Le Quotidien]. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Quotidien}} [[Category:Newspapers published in Senegal]] [[Category:Dakar]] {{africa-newspaper-stub}} {{Senegal-stub}}

page.title: Little Ephraim Robin John and Ancona Robin Robin John

revision.comment: Shalor (Wiki Ed) moved page [[User:Labben18/sandbox]] to [[Little Ephraim Robin John and Ancona Robin Robin John]]
revision.text:
'''Little Ephraim Robin John and Ancona Robin Robin John''' were former slaves and members of the elite ruling family of [[Calabar|Old Town, Calabur]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XbEkAAAAQBAJ&q=Ancona+Robin+Robin+John&dq=Ancona+Robin+Robin+John&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiB4JmKtILfAhWp8YMKHVttDzQ4ChDoAQg2MAM|title=The American Promise, Volume A: A History of the United States: To 1800|last=Roark|first=James L.|last2=Johnson|first2=Michael P.|last3=Cohen|first3=Patricia Cline|last4=Stage|first4=Sarah|last5=Hartmann|first5=Susan M.|date=2012-03-01|publisher=Macmillan Higher Education|year=|isbn=9781457626524|location=|pages=123-124|language=en}}</ref> Both were captured and sold into slavery by English traders while the King of Old Town, Grady King George, Little Ephraim's brother and Ancona's uncle, was negotiating trade with the Duke of New Town. The Robin Johns were deceived twice by ship captains promising to bring them home to Africa. Upon the second time the two were in England, where they petitioned the court system for their freedom.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Childs|first=Matt|date=2004|title=Captors to Captives to Christians to Calabar: Navigating the Boundaries of Slavery and Freedom in the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade|url=https://scholarcommons.sc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1196&context=hist_facpub|journal=Common-place|volume=5|pages=1-4|via=}}</ref>
The two men belonged to an ethnic group called Erik were seen as valuable assets because of their intelligence, as they spoke multiple languages including English, were literate, could negotiate, and had a strong knowledge of the inner workings of the slave trade.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://slaveryandremembrance.org/people/person/?id=PP012|title=Ancona Robin John and Little Ephraim Robin John {{!}} Slavery and Remembrance|website=slaveryandremembrance.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref>
== Attack and Capture == By the mid 1700's a bitter rivalry had formed between Old Town and New Town in Old Calabar. In 1767 trade negotiations between Grady King George and Duke Ephriam of New Town turned bitter, which stalled the typical slave-trading operation.<ref name=":1" /> New Town's slave traders then recruited the help of British ship captains to ambush those involved in the slave trade in Old Town, during which hundreds of men were slaughtered and hundreds of men enslaved.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780195382075.001.0001/acref-9780195382075-e-1760|title=Robin, John, Little Ephraim and Ancona - Oxford Reference|language=en|doi=10.1093/acref/9780195382075.001.0001/acref-9780195382075-e-1760|access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref> While the city was focused on the ambush, a British captain was able to capture Little Ephraim and Ancona.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U1lCZYT2TWEC&pg=PA6&dq=Ancona+Robin+Robin+John&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiv9IbisILfAhVq6YMKHR3dCJgQ6AEILjAB#v=onepage&q=Ancona%20Robin%20Robin%20John&f=false|title=The Substance of the Evidence of Sundry Persons on the Slave-trade: Collected in the Course of a Tour Made in the Autumn of the Year 1788|last=Clarkson|first=Thomas|date=1789|publisher=James Phillips|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qhe6NR-1KlwC&pg=PT60&dq=Ancona+Robin+Robin+John&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiv9IbisILfAhVq6YMKHR3dCJgQ6AEIVjAI#v=onepage&q=Ancona%20Robin%20Robin%20John&f=false|title=The Atlantic in World History|last=Kupperman|first=Karen Ordahl|date=2012-08-08|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199986552|language=en}}</ref>
== Captivity ==
=== Dominca === Once captured, their odyssey began on Captain Bivins ship the ''Duke of York'' which set sail for Dominica in the Caribbean. The pair were sold together to a French physician, which scholar Randy Sparks states was extremely uncommon. After being on the island less than a year, Captain William Sharp of Liverpool on one of his regular trips to the island discovered the two Robin Johns. He promised to return both Little Ephraim Robin John and Ancona Robin Robin John back to Africa if they could make it to his ship before he left. In one of the letters that the Robin Johns sent the pair stated that they were "determined to get home".<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/221175566|title=The two princes of Calabar : an eighteenth-century Atlantic odyssey|last=J.|first=Sparks, Randy|date=2008|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=9780674032057|oclc=221175566}}</ref> Escaping at night, both Little Ephraim Robin John and Ancona Robin Robin John were able to make it to Captain William Sharp's ship. Once there, they discovered that they had been tricked, as Captain William Smith had no intention of sailing to Africa. He instead sailed up the coast of North America and docked in Virginia where the Robin Johns were once again sold.
=== Virginia === Once in Virginia, Captain William Sharp sold Little Ephraim Robin John and Ancona Robin Robin John to John Thompson of Williamsburg, Virginia.<ref name=":1" /> John Thompson was a trader and often took the Robin Johns to sea with him. He was a man with a temper and often beat the Robin Johns.<ref name=":0" /> In March of 1772, John Thompson died. Shortly after Thompson's death, Captain Terence O'Neil sailed the ''Greyhound'' into Virginia. O'Neil had previously sailed from England to Old Calabar, where he picked up 132 slaves to transport to South Carolina. After delivering the slaves O'Neil sailed to Virginia where two of his sailors, who were from Old Town, recognized the Robin Johns.<ref name=":0" /> Aware of the details of the ambush where they were captured, these sailors urged Captain O'Neil to take action. Captain O'Neil offered the Robin Johns a trip home if they could escape at night and board his ship. Little Ephraim Robin John and Ancona Robin Robin John were able to escape and board the ''Greyhound'', which was headed to Bristol, England, a major slave-trading post.
=== England === Upon arriving in England O'Neil transferred the Robin Johns to another ship that was headed back to Virginia, with plans to sell them again. The Robin Johns spent two weeks locked in a ship before they sent a letter to the prominent slave trader Thomas Jones, who knew the Robin Johns personally, as he had made many trips to Old Calabar in the 1760s. Jones had formed close relationships with the ruling family of Old Town. Immediately after the ambush Grady King George had written to Thomas Jones, asking for his help with bringing his brother and nephew home.<ref name=":0" />
==== Court Case in England ====
Through Thomas Jones, the Robin Johns petitioned for their freedom. Jones used the 1772 ruling on the [[Somerset v Stewart|James Somerset]] case, attempting to use Habeas Corpus to free the Robin Johns. A judge ruled that the Robin Johns were free and could not be returned to America to be sold again.<ref name=":2" /> After being declared free, the two traveled back to Calabur.<ref name=":2" />
== Later life == While in Bristol the Robin Johns interacted with Charles Wesley and converted to Methodism.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5a84efcfa8b2b01c39eb110f/t/5b89e31670a6ad81f193893c/1535763223263/Cruickshank+Aldersgate_7_September_2009.pdf|title=CHARLES WESLEY, THE MEN OF OLD CALABAR, AND THE ABOLITION OF SLAVERY|last=Cruickshank|first=Johanna|date=|website=Aldersgate Papers V7|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:African people]] [[Category:Former slaves]]

'''Melka Kuntureመልካ ቁንጥሬ''' is a [[Paleolithic]] site in the upper Awash Valley, [[Ethiopia]]. It is located 50 kilometers south of [[Addis Ababa]] by road, across the [[Awash River]] from the village of Melka Awash, with a latitude and longitude of {{coord|8|42|9|N|38|36|30|E}}. Three waterfalls lie downstream of the bridge across the Awash here, which provides access south to [[Butajira]].<ref>Philip Briggs, ''Ethiopia: The Bradt Travel Guide'', 3rd edition (Chalfont St Peters: Bradt, 2002), p. 374</ref>
== History of Research == The site, discovered by Gerard Dekker in 1963, was surveyed by Gérard Bailloud in 1964, and then systematically explored by a French mission directed by Jean Chavaillon (1965-1982 / 1993-1995). Since 1999, an Italian mission directed by Marcello Piperno for the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the University of Rome “La Sapienza” has worked at the site in agreement with the Authority for Research and Conservation of Cultural Heritage of the Ethiopian Ministry of Culture and Tourism and the Oromia Culture and Tourism Bureau.
== Archaeological Sequences == Archaeologists have uncovered over 30 occupation sites at Melka Kunture. The finds are dated by volcanic depositions left by eruptions of [[Mount Zuqualla]], northeast of Melka Kunture.<ref>Paul B. Henze, ''Layers of Time'' (New York: Palgrave, 2000), p. 8</ref>
The sequence begins with the [[Oldowan]] site of Karre, about 1.7 million years old, which can be correlated to level B of Gombore I, on the right bank of the Awash. A probably contemporaneous Oldowan site is documented at Garba IV. The magneto-stratigraphic sequence of Jaramillo lies between Tuff A, which overlies the Oldowan sites, and Tuff B, which is dated between 1.0 and 0.84 million years ago. Some important sites, such as Garba XII and Simbiro III, datable to a transitional phase from the late Oldowan to the Early [[Acheulean]] (Garba XII) or to an archaic phase of the Acheulean (Simbiro), also lie within this chronological span.
A later phase of the African Acheulean is well represented by several sites in the area of Gombore II (dated to about 0.8 mya). The latest Acheulean site is Garba I, dated to ca. 0.5 mya, while the end of this long sequence is represented, at Melka Kunture, by the site of Garba III, approximately dated to 0.2 mya, which can be regarded as a transitional site towards the [[Middle Stone Age]]. Some of the above-listed levels yielded hominid remains: a humerus fragment of H. cf. erectus at Gombore I; a hemimandible of a H. cf. erectus child at Garba IV; two [[Homo erectus|H. erectus]] skull fragments at Gombore II; and three [[Archaic humans|archaic H. sapiens]] skull fragments at Garba III.
The East African [[Later Stone Age]] is poorly documented at Melka Kunture, being represented so far by some finds at Wofi and Kella. A little less than 7 km from Melka Kunture, in a site known as Balchit, are imposing outcrops of obsidian. As recent analyses from samples from several sites in Melka Kunture bear out, these outcrops were used, ever since the earliest Oldowan phases, as an important source of raw material. The exploitation of obsidian in the Melka region went on until historical times, leaving numerous and extensive accumulations of tens of thousands of blades, cores, and scars of this volcanic rock.
== Exhibits == A museum was built at the site by the Oromia Culture and Tourism Commission with financial assistance from the [[European Community]], consisting of four buildings with exhibits—one on [[prehistoric Africa]], another on geology and volcanology, a third on paleoanthropology, the fourth on the prehistory of Melka Kunture. There is also an "Open Air Museum," which displays the excavation of two [[Acheulean]] sites that have been dated to 0.8 million years BP.<ref>[http://www.melkakunture.it "Melka Kunture - Home"], University of Rome, "La Sapienza", Dipartimento di Scienze dell’Antichità.</ref> Currently (May, 2016) a new museum is under construction, which is funded by the World Bank. <ref>As told by guide during site visit.</ref>
== Notes == {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.melkakunture.it "Melka Kunture"], University of Rome, "La Sapienza", Dipartimento di Scienze dell’Antichità. * Jean Chavaillon and Marcello Piperno (editors), [http://www.melkakunture.it/biblio/monograph/melka-I-XII_link.pdf ''Studies on the Early Paleolithic site of Melka Kunture, Ethiopia'']. Florence: Istituto Italiano di Preistoria e Protostoria, 2004.
[[Category:Archaeological sites in Ethiopia]]

{{unreferenced|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Norway}} "Mil etter mil" | image = [[File:Mil_etter_mil.jpg|250 px]] | caption = | year = 1978 | country = Norway | artist = [[Jahn Teigen]] | as = | with = | language = Norwegian | languages = | composer = Kai Eide | lyricist = Kai Eide / english lyric by David Cooper | conductor = Carsten Klouman | place = 20th | points = 0 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1978no from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Casanova | prev_link = Casanova (Anita Skorgan song) | next = Oliver | next_link = Oliver (song) }} '''"Mil etter mil"''' was the [[Norway|Norwegian]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1978]], performed in [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] by [[Jahn Teigen]].
The song is a ballad, with Teigen describing his long journey to find someone and telling this person that he simply cannot walk any further - having walked "[[Scandinavian mile|mile]] after mile" already.
By all accounts, Teigen did not like [[Carsten Klouman]]'s brass-dominated jazz arrangement; when the song was issued as a record a few weeks after the contest, it was in a rock version with more drums and guitar, a bit of strings and no brass. This version was recorded in Norwegian and English (English lyric by American singer/songwriter David Cooper), it was a huge hit in Norway and was also issued in many other countries. Teigen also recorded a mock-Russian version on his best-selling comedy album ''[[Brakara]]'' with the group [[Prima Vera (band)|Prima Vera]]; this version had most of the guitars mixed out.
The song was performed second on the night, following [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]'s [[Colm C. T. Wilkinson]] with "[[Born To Sing (song)|Born To Sing]]" and preceding [[Italy]]'s [[Ricchi e Poveri]] with "[[Questo amore]]". At the close of voting, it had received no points, placing 20th (last) in a field of 20.
It was succeeded as [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest|Norwegian representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1979|1979 contest]] by [[Anita Skorgan]] (who later married Teigen) with "[[Oliver (song)|Oliver]]".
{{Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1978}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mil Etter Mil}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Norway]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1978]] [[Category:1978 songs]] [[Category:Eurovision songs that scored no points]] [[Category:RCA Victor singles]] [[Category:1978 singles]]
{{norway-stub}}

'''National symbols of Kosovo''' are the symbols that are used in [[Kosovo]] to represent what is unique about the nation, reflecting different aspects of its cultural life and history. ==Official symbols== {|class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" !style=background:#FFDEAD;|Type !style=background:#FFDEAD;|Image !style=background:#FFDEAD;|Symbol |- !
[[National flag]] |
[[File:Flag of Kosovo.svg|120px|border]] |
'''[[Flag of Kosovo]]'''
The flag of Kosovo shows six white stars in an arc above a golden map of Kosovo on a blue field. The stars symbolise Kosovo's six major ethnic groups. |- !
[[Coat of arms]] |
[[File:Coat of arms of Kosovo.svg|90px]] |
'''[[Coat of arms of Kosovo]]'''
The coat of arms shows six white stars in an arc above a solid golden shape of Kosovo as seen on a standard projection map, placed on a rounded triangular shield with a blue field and a golden border. Its central figures, the stars and the shape, are also the content of the new blue flag of Kosovo, already adopted at the same time. |- !
[[National anthem]] | {{listen | filename = National Anthem of the Republic of Kosovo.ogg | title = Europe (anthem) | description = National anthem of Kosovo | format = [[Ogg]] }} |
'''[[Europe (anthem)|Europe]]''' is the official anthem of Kosovo. It has no official lyrics, but unofficial lyrics have been written for it. It was adopted on 11 June 2008 and chosen because it contained no references to any specific ethnic group. |- |} ==Unofficial symbols== {|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" !style=background:#FFDEAD;|Symbol !style=background:#FFDEAD;|Image !style=background:#FFDEAD;|Remarks |- |
'''[[Monument]]'''
'''[[Newborn monument]]'''
|
[[File:Newborn Pristina February 2013.jpg|150px|The Newborn monument inaugurated for Kosovo's Independence on the 17/02/2008. Repainted painted with flags of the countries that have recognized Kosovo's independence.]] | |- |} {{Europe topic|National symbols of}} [[Category:Kosovan culture]] [[Category:National symbols of Kosovo]] {{Kosovo-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Shinan |local = 天主教施南教区 |latin = Dioecesis Scenanensis |country = [[China]] |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hankou|Hankou]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hankou|Hankou]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = |cocathedral = |area_km2 = |population = |population_as_of = |catholics = |catholics_percent= |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Sede Vacante]] |metro_archbishop = [[Sede Vacante]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Shinan/Shíhnan/Enshi''' ({{lang-la|Scenanen(sis)}}, {{zh|施南, 恩施}}) is a (dormant?) [[suffragan]] Latin [[diocese]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hankou|archbishopric of Hankou]] in central China, yet depends on the missionary [[Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples]].
Its episcopal see is the city of [[Shinan]] (presently known as [[Enshi City|Enshi]]). No statistics available. Vacant since its sole incumbent's death in 1942, without [[apostolic administrator]] since 1950.
== History == * Established on June 14, 1938 as '''[[Apostolic Vicariate]] of Shinan''' 施南 / Shihnan / de Shinan (Latin) , on territory split off from the then [[Apostolic Vicariate of Yichang]] 宜昌 * Promoted on April 11, 1946 as '''Diocese of Shinan''' 施南 / Enshi 恩施 (中文) / Shíhnan / Scenanen(sis) (Latin). <ref>http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/shih0.htm GCatholic.org</ref>
==Episcopal ordinaries== (all [[Roman rite]]) <ref>http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/shih0.htm GCatholic.org</ref>
;''Apostolic Vicar of Shinan 施南 * Father [[John Baptist Hu Ruo-han]] (胡若翰) (Chinese) (February 13, 1940 – death 1942), [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Abbir Maius]] (1940.02.13 – 1942)
;''Suffragan Bishops of Shinan 施南 *''[[Apostolic Administrator]] [[Noël Gubbels]], [[Order of Friars Minor]] (O.F.M.) (born Belgium) (顧學德) (April 11, 1946 – November 18, 1950), while first Bishop of mother see [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Yichang|Yichang]] 宜昌 (China) (1946.04.11 – 1950.11.18) * ''indefinite vacancy
== See also == {{Portal|Christianity in China}} * [[List of Catholic dioceses in China]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Sources and external links == * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/shih0.htm GCatholic.org - data for all sections] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dshih.html Catholic Hierarchy]

{{Infobox organization | name = SERVIR Mekong Project | image = | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | map = <!-- optional --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = <!-- optional --> | map2 = | abbreviation = SERVIR-Mekong Project | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date and years ago|2015}} | extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> | type = | status = Active | headquarters = | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | region_served = [[Southeast Asia]] | membership = [[Myanmar]], [[Cambodia]], [[Laos]], [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]] | leader_title = Member | leader_name = <!-- name of leader --> | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | affiliations = <!-- if any --> | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{url|http://servir.adpc.net/about}} | remarks = | former name = }} '''SERVIR-Mekong project''' is a joint initiative by the US agency for International Development ([[USAID]]), [[NASA]] and five other countries which are Myanmar, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam. "Servir" is a [[Spanish language|Spanish]] word which means "to serve". The project aims to use the latest technologies to help the [[Mekong River|Mekong river]] region protect its vital ecosystem. It helps to connect USAID's development network with NASA's technology and satellite data to provide mapping information and satellite imagery.<ref name="preventionweb.net">{{Cite web|title = Asia: USAID and NASA today launched 'SERVIR-Mekong' - News - Professional Resources - PreventionWeb.net|url = http://www.preventionweb.net/english/professional/news/v.php?id=45582|website = www.preventionweb.net|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Introducing SERVIR-Mekong – NASA’s New Environmental Monitoring Project | date=20 September 2015 |website=Envirotech Online |url=http://www.envirotech-online.com/news/environmental-laboratory/7/breaking_news/introducing_servir-mekong_nasas_new_environmental_monitoring_project/36065/ |accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref>
==History== The first such experimental hub was launched in Panama in 2005 to serve the near region. The project was initially undertook by researchers at NASA's [[Marshall Space Flight Center]] in [[Alabama]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = USAID and NASA today launched "SERVIR-Mekong"|url = http://reliefweb.int/report/world/usaid-and-nasa-today-launched-servir-mekong|website = ReliefWeb|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> In the Earth Observation Summit, 2007, SERVIR was recognized as a model for the effectuation of the Global Earth Observation System of Systems (GEOSS). In 2010, the organisation had presence in Himalayas when a hub, SERVIR-Himalaya, was established at the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD) in Kathmandu, Nepal.<ref>{{Cite web|title = SERVIR Himalaya|url = http://www.icimod.org/servir-himalaya|website = www.icimod.org|accessdate = 2015-11-08}}</ref> The organization has launched similar projects in past for other regions also like Latin America, Africa and Asia.
==Target== The project stresses the vital issues associated in the [[Mekong River Basin|Mekong river basin]] region which encompasses all the five countries which are also known as ''the rice bowl of Asia''. The project will also allow these countries to better deal with natural disasters and climate studies like green house gas emissions and its effects. It also enables them to use their water resources more efficiently.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Knowledge Products|url = http://servir.adpc.net/knowledge-products|website = SERVIR MEKONG|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref>
==Geographical and strategical importance== [[File:Mekongbasin.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Mekong River Basin Area is about 5000km long]] The Mekong basin is covers almost {{convert|5000|km|mi}} from Tibetan plateau up to the South China Sea region. It gives livelihood to almost 40 million people. The environment is considered one of the most volatile ones in the world. The project uses space applications and helps to create geospatial data which is later analyzed to avoid natural disasters like floods and others in the lower Mekong region.<ref name="preventionweb.net"/>
==Implementation== The implementation of the project is undertaken by the Asian Disaster Preparedness Center (ADPC) in consortium with [[Stockholm Environment Institute]] (SEI), Spatial Informatics Group (SIG) and Deltares. The first phase of the project was launched on 31 August 2015.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Home {{!}} SERVIR-Mekong|url = http://index.servirmekong.opendata.arcgis.com/|website = index.servirmekong.opendata.arcgis.com|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref>
==Future perspectives== SERVIR-Mekong is an example of the technical collaboration in the region and development of a common analysis. It also aims to see environmental planning agencies leading in technical support and take better development decisions. SERVIR has also served in development of more than 30 countries of Latin America, Africa and Asia which includes providing tools and training to thousands of people of the region.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Earsc: NASA and USAID Launch SERVIR-Mekong|url = http://earsc.org/news/nasa-and-usaid-launch-servir-mekong|website = Earsc: NASA and USAID Launch SERVIR-Mekong|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{GMSARN}}

[http://www.telesat.lu www.telesat.lu] }} [[File:TéléSAT-Numérique.png|thumb|Original logo used at launch]] '''TéléSAT Numérique''', commonly known as '''TéléSAT''', is a [[Belgian]] [[satellite]] [[subscription]] [[television]] [[company]] aimed at the [[French language|French]]-speaking community, also offering a [[Triple play (telecommunications)|triple play]] solution ([[satellite television]], [[Internet]], and [[landline]] telephone). It is available to residents in [[Belgium]] or [[Luxembourg]]. Its parent company is the [[M7 Group S.A.]] which is also the parent company of [[Canal Digitaal]] in the [[Netherlands]], [[TV Vlaanderen]] also in Belgium but aimed at the [[Flemish]] speaking community, Austriasat in [[Austria]], AustriaSat Magyarország in [[Hungary]], CS Link in the [[Czech Republic]] and Skylink in [[Slovakia]] In 2010 the operator added the possibility to add a selection of Flemish stations to a client's subscription by adding the option "Espace TV Vlaanderen" at an additional monthly cost but which requires a triple [[Low-noise block downconverter|LNB]] or motorised [[satellite dish]]. == Packages == As of the 27th of March 2015 the company offers a choice of three packages to be used in conjunction with either bought or rented [[DVB-S2]] [[Set-top box]]es (STB) to receive MPEG-4 AVC/H.264 services (backwards compatible with [[DVB-S]] technology) and all of which include a built-in [[smartcard]] reader which uses the [[Nagravision]] version 3 "Merlin" [[encryption]] to protect the transmissions. '''''Basic light'''''
The '''''Basic light''''' packages offers 27 [[TV Station]]s of which 6 are broadcast in [[High-definition television|High Definition]] and 1 is an Adult TV station) and also 8 of the [[Belgian]] [[French language|French]] speaking [[national (distribution)|national]] [[radio station]]s. '''''Basic'''''
The '''''Basic''''' packages offers 55 [[TV Station]]s of which 12 are broadcast in [[High-definition television|High Definition]] and 2 are an Adult TV stations) and 8 of the [[Belgian]] [[French language|French]] speaking [[national (distribution)|national]] [[radio station]]s and 5 of the [[Belgian]] [[Dutch language|Dutch]] speaking [[national (distribution)|national]] [[radio station]]s. '''''Basic+'''''
The '''''Basic+''''' packages offers 73 [[TV Station]]s of which 33 are broadcast in [[High-definition television|High Definition]] and 3 are an Adult TV stations) and 8 of the [[Belgian]] [[French language|French]] speaking [[national (distribution)|national]] [[radio station]]s and 5 of the [[Belgian]] [[Dutch language|Dutch]] speaking [[national (distribution)|national]] [[radio station]]s. All subscription packages give access to all unencrypted Free-to-air (FTA) stations broadcasting from the [[Eutelsat]] Hotbird satellites at 13° East and the [[SES S.A.|SES]] Astra 1 satellites broadcasting at 19.2° East and Astra 3B satellite at 23.5° East and Astra 2 satellites at 28.2/28.5° East however to ensure the full channel line up will require a Triple or Quad [[Low-noise block downconverter|LNB]], multifeed accessory or a [[DiSEqC]] or [[Universal Satellites Automatic Location System]] (USALS) motorised [[Satellite dish]] === Legend === {| border="1" cellpadding="1" ! style="border-collapse:collapse; font-size:90%; text-align:center; width:100%;" |- | style="width:10%; background:#ffff80;"| Basic light | style="width:10%; background:#9a95ff;"| Basic | style="width:10%; background:#d8a8ff;"| Basic Plus | style="width:10%; background:#fff;"| Free to Air (FTA)

revision.text:
{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = World Space Week |type = International |longtype = United Nations |image = World_Space_Week_%E2%80%93_Stacked.png |imagesize = 150px |caption = World Space Week logo |observedby = Worldwide |begins = October 4 |ends = October 10 |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = |frequency = annual |duration = 7 days }}
'''World Space Week''' ('''WSW''') is an annual holiday observed from 4–10 October in various parts of the world, including [[Europe]] and [[Asia]]. World Space Week is officially defined as "an international celebration of science and technology, and their contribution to the betterment of the human condition."<ref>[https://www.un.org/en/events/spaceweek/background.shtml World Space Week], General Assembly, The United Nations</ref>
==History== On December 6, 1999, The United Nations General Assembly declared World Space Week as an annual event celebration to be commemorated between October 4–10. The choice of dates was based on recognition of two important dates in space history: the launch of the first human-made Earth satellite, [[Sputnik 1]], on October 4, 1957; and the signing of the [[Outer Space Treaty]] on October 10, 1967.<ref>[http://www.worldspaceweek.org/wsw/index.php World Space Week] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012040332/http://www.worldspaceweek.org/wsw/index.php |date=2012-10-12 }} UN General Assembly</ref>
World Space Week is the largest annual space event in the world.<ref>[https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=43212&Cr=outer+space&Cr1=#.UHePC65rMT4 UN launches into World Space Week highlighting contributions of space science to humanity] The United Nations News Center; October 4, 2012</ref> In 2017, World Space Week was celebrated with over 3,700 events in 80 countries. Events included school activities, exhibitions, government events, and special activities at planetaria around the world.
==Annual themes== Each year, a theme for World Space Week is established by the Board of Directors of World Space Week Association.
Under the theme "Exploring New Worlds in Space", many events of World Space Week 2017 focused on plans for human exploration of space and recent discoveries of Earth-like planets in nearby solar systems. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldspaceweek.org/annual_reports.html |title=Report on World Space Week 2000/2007 |publisher=Worldspaceweek.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121008084639/http://www.worldspaceweek.org/annual_reports.html |archivedate=2012-10-08 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldspaceweek.org/annual_reports.html |title=UN Report on World Space Week 2007, ST/SPACE/38 |publisher=Worldspaceweek.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121008084639/http://www.worldspaceweek.org/annual_reports.html |archivedate=2012-10-08 |df= }}</ref>
In 2018, the theme for World Space Week will be "Space Unites the World." This in part recognizes the historic UNISPACE+50 gathering to be held in Vienna this year.
==Activities and observances== The World Space Week Association is a non-government, non-profit organization which is supported by national coordinators in over 50 nations. It is led by an all volunteer Board of Directors including [[Buzz Aldrin]], [[Bill Nye]], [[Tom Hanks]], [[Elon Musk]], [[Dorin-Dumitru Prunariu]], [[Max Grimard]], [[Lisa LaBonte]], and space leaders from around the world. Its goals are to educate people around the world about the benefits that they receive from space, encourage use of space for sustainable economic development, foster enthusiastic education and interest in science and cooperation between nations through space outreach and education.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldspaceweek.org/wsw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=65&Itemid=3 |title=About World Space Week |publisher=Worldspaceweek.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012023604/http://www.worldspaceweek.org/wsw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=65&Itemid=3 |archivedate=2012-10-12 |df= }}</ref>
The association provides resources for educators in grade K-12.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldspaceweek.org/wsw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=107&Itemid=120 |title=Teacher Activity Guide |publisher=Worldspaceweek.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213032935/http://www.worldspaceweek.org/wsw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=107&Itemid=120 |archivedate=2013-12-13 |df= }}</ref>
A Calendar of Events from nations celebrating World Space Week is available.<ref>[http://www.worldspaceweek.org/wsw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&catid=7:basics&id=97:events&whichYear=2012&Itemid=135 Calendar of Events 2012] World Space Week; The United Nations</ref>
